Since unification in 1910, [[South Africa]] has used a range of '''[[National Symbols|national symbols]]''' to identify the country: coats of arms, official seals, flags, national anthems, and floral, bird, animal, and other emblems.
==Coats of arms== [[File:Coat of Arms of South Africa (1932-2000).svg|100px|right|Coat of arms 1910]] * '''[[Coat of arms of South Africa|1910 coat of arms]]''' - granted by [[King George V]] in 1910, and used until 2000.<ref name=nps> Brownell, F.G. (1993). ''National and Provincial Symbols''</ref> * '''[[Coat of arms of South Africa|2000 coat of arms]]''' - introduced by the [[Thabo Mbeki|Mbeki administration]] in 2000.<ref name=ca>''Government Gazette'' no 21131 (28 April 2000)</ref>
==Seals== * '''Great Seal of the Union''' - authorised by King George V in 1910, and used until 1937 on state documents signed by the [[Governor-General of South Africa|governor-general]].<ref name=nps/> * '''Royal Great Seal of the Union''' - authorised by the Royal Executive Functions and Seals Act 1934, and used until 1961 on state documents signed by the monarch on the advice of the South African government.<ref name=res>Royal Executive Functions and Seals Act 1934</ref> * '''Royal Signet of the Union''' - authorised by the Royal Executive Functions and Seals Act 1934, and used until 1961 on state documents signed by the monarch on the advice of the South African government.<ref name=res/> * '''Governor-General's Great Seal''' - authorised by [[King George VI]] in 1937, and used until 1961 on state documents signed by the [[Governor-General of South Africa|governor-general]].<ref name=lp>''Government Gazette'' no 2533 (6 June 1938)</ref> * '''Seal of the Republic''' - authorised by the Republic of South Africa Constitution Act 1961, and used on state documents signed by the [[President of South Africa|(state) president]].<ref name=con1>Republic of South Africa Constitution Acts 1961, 1983, 1993</ref> The use of the seal has not been a constitutional requirement since 1997,<ref name=con2>Republic of South Africa Constitution 1996</ref> but its use continues nevertheless.
==Flags== ===National===
* '''[[Flag of South Africa|National Flag of the Union]]''' - authorised by the Union Flags and Nationality Act 1927, and introduced in 1928. Renamed the "National Flag of the Republic" in 1961,<ref name=con3>Republic of South Africa Constitution Act 1961</ref> it was used until 1994. * '''[[Flag of South Africa|National Flag]]''' - the current flag, introduced in 1994.
===Merchant ensign=== * '''[[Red Ensign]]''' defaced with the shield of the coat of arms - authorised by the [[Admiralty]] in 1910, for use on South African-registered merchant ships, and also used as an unofficial "national flag". From 1912, the shield was placed on a white disc.<ref name=nps/> The ensign was discontinued in 1960.<ref name=msa>Merchant Shipping Act 1951 w.e.f. 1 January 1960</ref> * Since 1960, the national flag has been used as the merchant ensign.<ref name=msa/>
===Civil ensign=== * '''[[Blue Ensign]]''' defaced with the shield of the coat of arms - authorised by the Admiralty in 1910, for use on South African government vessels. Superseded by the National Flag of the Union.<ref name=nps/>
===Head of state's flag=== * '''[[Union Jack]]''' defaced with the full coat of arms surrounded by acacia leaves and flowers - flown by the governor-general until 1931.<ref name=nps/> * '''Governor-General's flag''' - blue, displaying the royal crest between two ribands bearing the name of the country. Used from 1931 to 1961.<ref name=nps/> * '''State President's flag (1)''' - blue, displaying the national coat of arms below the letters SP. Used from 1961 to 1984.<ref name=nps/> * '''State President's flag (2)''' - orange, white, and blue triangles, displaying the national coat of arms below the letters SP. Used from 1984 to 1994.<ref name=nps/>
==National Anthem== * '''''God Save the King (Queen)''''' - used from 1910 to 1957. * '''''[[Die Stem van Suid-Afrika]]''''' - used from 1938 to 1957 as joint anthem with ''God Save the King (Queen)''; from 1957 to 1994 as the sole national anthem; and from 1994 to 1997 as joint anthem with ''Nkosi sikelel' iAfrika''. * '''''[[Nkosi Sikelel' iAfrika]]''''' - used from 1994 to 1997 as joint anthem with ''Die Stem''. * '''''[[National Anthem of South Africa]]''''' - shortened versions of ''Nkosi sikelel' iAfrika'' and ''Die Stem'', with altered words, combined into a single anthem, and used since 1997.<ref name=na>''Government Gazette'' no 18341 (10 October 1997)</ref>
